title: How do i collect money owed to me from a business that is closing?
question: A local family-owned business is closing up shop, but they owe me money. Is there any way i can still collect what they owe me? The owner does own other business, they just aren't all the same business (restaurant, hair salon, etc)
answers: Absent a very strong case of fraud, or your holding enforceable lien rights/security interests in the defaulting company's AR or inventory, unfortunately you will need to obtain a judgment against the business owner entity before you can execute against any remaining assets, or otherwise try to trace assets to other companies and property held by the business owner. A competent business litigation attorney should be able to direct you in this matter. But remember that litigation is a very expensive proposition and recovery of your litigation fees and costs is going to be problematic.

I agree with the others. However, one important issue was not mentioned. Getting a judgment for the debt makes sense. You may or may not get payment by that activiity. If, by any chance, however, this business were to file for bankruptcy under the United States Bankruptcy Code, any monies you take from the debtor within 90 days that immediately precede the bankruptcy filing, those monies can be recovered by the debtor in bankruptcy or a trustee apointed over a liquidation. So, for example if the debt is $5,000 and you recovered $1,000 even after getting that judgment, you are likely to be paying that into the bankrupt estate. That said, many small business merely close the doors, let the equipment go to a SECURED creditor and ignore any UNSECURED debts, in which case only a personally guaranteed indebtedness would be a source from which you might collect. I will add this, it appears that the "local family-owned business" had good business and legal planning advice when starting up. That appears to be excellent preventive legal advice for that family. Good luck.

It's possible the owner owns all these businesses personally running them under DBA names (easy to look up in the County), and not as corporations (also easy to look up at the Secretary of State). If that is the case you can collect easily from any of the businesses-..

(if he is operating in a dba name-quickest and cheapest thing to do is to file small claims case against the individual AND the individual dba the business that is closing--dollar limit goes up to $10,000--you will get a hearing in about 45 days and if you have documentation to prove your case, you will get a judgment against the owner and the DBA name; there are a number of easy ways to go and collect--the old business closing most definitely will still have an active bank account in order to cash checks that will continue to come in; that bank account can easily be garnished...lots of things---...If it is a corporation, you can bring a small claims against the corporation up to $5,000.

you do need to consult with an attorney to assist you with all these and determine the official owner of the business, and properly advise and advise you.

As mentioned by my colleague, It depends on the type of business - and whether they truly ran it as a separate legal entity. I am assuming you did not record any lien against any assets of the business. How as the debt incurred by the business? Services? Equipment sold to them? There are many factors in what steps you need to take.

You need to contact a lawyer immediately to discuss your options. Whether the family is liable is dependent on whether there is a corporate entity (corporation, LLC, etc.) that owns the assets. Time is of the essence, as assets have a way of disappearing in cases like this. Find a good business litigation lawyer in your area right away.

You will have to first sue them and obtain a judgment, then you can possibly collect.

Without a judgment, there is no legal force to compel them to pay you.
